questions.text: The given image of the cell wall belongs to which of the following organisms ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neisseria meningitidis Presence of lipooligosaccharide, pilus and capsule confirm the organism to be Neisseria.

Highyeild:

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci) . It contains two important pathogens : Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Can be distinguished by the presence of a capsule in N.meningitidis and Antibiotic resistance imparting plasmids in N.Gonorrhoea Lipooligosaccharide component of the outer membrane of N. meningitidis acts as an endotoxin and is responsible for septic shock and hemorrhage due to the destruction of red blood cells Other known protein s that are involved in adhesion and invasion include the Type IV pilin adhesin which mediates attachment of the bacterium to the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx

Extraedge:

Many bacteria secrete a viscid material around the cell. When this is organized into a sharply defined structure as in S.pneumonia, it is known as the capsule. When it is a loose un-demarcated secretion it is called the Slime layer. Demonstration of capsule S. lime has little affinity for basic dyes and is not visible in Gram-stained smears. Capsules may be readily demonstrated by negative staining in wet films with India ink , when they are seen as clear halos around the bacteria, against a black background Capsular material is antigenic and may be demonstrated by serological methods. When a suspension of a capsulated bacteria is mixed with its specific anti- capsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears 'swollen' due to an increase in its refractivity : Quellung reaction Types of capsules Organisms Capsules Streptococcus pneumonia Haemophilus influenzae Klebsiella pneumonia Neisseria meningitidis Salmonella typhii Clostridium perfringens Bordetella pertussis Polysaccharide capsule Streptococcus pyogenes Hyaluronic acid Bacillus anthracis Polypeptide(poly-d-capsule)

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rubella Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission

Highyeild:

Maximum risk of transmission in case of rubella is in the first trimester, c ausing abortions and severe fetal defects. Classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome is Deafness Cataract Congenital heart disease Rubella is transmitted primarily through direct or droplet contact from nasopharyngeal secretions. Humans are the only natural hosts. In temperate climates, infections usually occur during late winter and early spring. The average incubation period of rubella virus is 17 days , with a range of 12 to 23 days.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Herpes simplex infection can be acquired in utero, intrapartum/perinatally, or during the neonatal period. The intrauterine infection causes skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and microcephaly/ hydra Intrapartum infection presents with either: Skin, eye, and mouth disease Encephalitis Disseminated disease with sepsis-like presentation Option B. Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequels is hearing loss. Option D. Hepatitis B virus is associated with significant perinatal transmission. The most important risk factor that determines perinatal transmission is HBeAg.

questions.text: A Pregnant woman comes for an antenatal check-up. She has a history of stillbirth at 28 weeks in her previous pregnancy. She also has a history of multiple sexual partners and vaguely remembers having a painless ulcer on her vulva prior to her last pregnancy. What would be the first step of investigation for this lady?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VDRL test History of painless vulvar ulcer in her last pregnancy and stillbirth at 28 weeks, with a history of multiple sexual partners is suggestive of Syphilis. The first step should be to do a confirmatory investigation which is VDRL

Highyeild:

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum Incubation period: 9 to 90 days Primary lesion: papules which progress to the genital ulcer (Hard chancre/ hunter Ian chancre) Single ulcer with clean base Induration present Nontender No bleeding on touch Inguinal lymph nodes: Bilaterally enlarged, non-tender, rubbery consistency Diagnosis: Dark field microscopy Secondary syphilis : Symmetric, non-pruritic, polymorphic rash over palms and soles Mucosal lesion: Condyloma Lata Snail liveck ulcer Latent & tertiary Syphilis- Gummatous syphilis: Rubbery nodules break to form ulcers with a punched-out edge Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin Primary syphilis (first stage): A round, painless, usually hard sore (chancre) appears on the genitals, anus or elsewhere. Heal in 1-4 months Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral/bilateral, rubbery inguinal nodes Dory flop sign Secondary syphilis: Non-itchy rash, with no vesicles on the palms and soles - Most common Condyloma lata Moth eaten alopecia Snail track ulcers Pigmentary plaques Generalized diffuse non tender lymphadenopathy Tertiary syphilis: Gummatous syphilis Cardiac : Aortitis & Aortic aneurysm CNS : Tabes dorsalis Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. Patient is clinically asymptomatic but serological evidence of infection can be found Early latent syphilis : Within 1 year of infection Late latent syphilis : After 1 year of infection Congenital Syphilis Hutchinson’s Triad Hutchinson teeth ( Mulberry molars ) Interstitial keratitis Sensorineural deafness

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Karyotyping analysis is not necessary in this condition Option C. Pap smear should be performed when there is suspicion of Carcinoma cervix Option D. USG has minimal diagnostic function in case of suspected syphilis

questions.text: A CSF sample of an elderly male presenting with meningitis is subjected to gram staining and revealed gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following is true regarding the motility of the causative agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Motile at 25 Degree Celsius and immotile at 37 degree Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: Motile at 37 Degree Celsius and immotile at 25 degree Celsius

questions.correct_answer: A. Motile at 25 Degree Celsius and immotile at 37 degree Celsius
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Motile at 25 Degree Celsius and immotile at 37 degree Celsius History of meningitis in an elderly male with a gram positive bacteria in CSF is more likely to be Listeria monocytogenes. Listeria monocytogenes is motile at room temperature(20-25 degree celsius) but not at 37 degree celsius.

Highyeild:

Listeria exhibits a characteristic slow tumbling end-over-end motility at 22-28°C but is non-motile at 37°C. This is because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This is known as differential motility as the motility pattern changes with a change in temperature. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram- positive bacillus. It can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C) , under conditions of low pH and high salt . So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen . The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin . This helps the bacteria to escape and causes septicemia. They are catalase-positive , will not produce H2S , and show beta hemolysis . This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following is a protozoan parasite that can be seen inside Kupffer cells?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leishmania donovanosis Leishmania donovani is a species of intracellular parasites belonging to the genus Leishmania, a group of haemoflagellate kinetoplastids that cause the disease leishmaniasis.

Highyeild:

It infects the mononuclear phagocyte system including spleen, liver and bone marrow. Infection is transmitted by species of sandfly belonging to the genus Phlebotomus in the Old World and Lutzomyia in the New World. Phlebotomus LIFE CYCLE OF KALA- AZAR Kala-azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a severe form of leishmaniasis caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani. It primarily affects the internal organs, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Fever: Persistent and prolonged fever is a hallmark symptom of kala-azar. The fever tends to be irregular and can be accompanied by chills and sweats. Splenomegaly : Enlargement of the spleen (splenomegaly) is a characteristic feature of kala-azar. The spleen can become massively enlarged, leading to discomfort or pain in the left upper abdomen. Leukopenia and Thrombocytopenia : The infection can lead to reduced levels of white blood cells (leukopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia), which can increase the risk of infections and bleeding. Lymphadenopathy : Enlarged lymph nodes, especially those near the spleen, liver, and abdomen, can occur in some cases.Edema: Swelling of the extremities, face, or abdomen due to fluid retention can occur.Darkening of the Skin: In some cases, individuals with kala-azar may develop a characteristic darkening of the skin, which is more noticeable in areas exposed to the sun. PKDL is characterized by the presence of skin lesions that can vary in appearance.Lesions can range from macules (flat, discolored spots) to papules (raised, small bumps) to nodules (larger, firm lesions).Lesions are usually found on the face, neck, upper body, and limbs. Anti-leishmanial medications , such as miltefosine, paromomycin, or sodium stibogluconate, are commonly used for treatment.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Toxoplasmosis gondii is a parasitic protozoan (specifically an apicomplexan) that causes toxoplasmosis. Found worldwide, T. gondii is capable of infecting virtually all warm-blooded animals, but felids are the only known definitive hosts in which the parasite may undergo sexual reproduction Option C .Babesia microti is a parasitic blood-borne piroplasm transmitted by deer ticks. B. microti is responsible for the disease babesiosis, a malaria-like disease which also causes fever and hemolysis. Option D. Plasmodium vivax is a protozoan parasite and a human pathogen. This parasite is the most frequent and widely distributed cause of recurring malaria.Although it is less virulent than Plasmodium falciparum , the deadliest of the five human malaria parasites, P. vivax malaria infections can lead to severe disease and death, often due to splenomegaly a pathologically enlarged spleen.

questions.text: A lady cleans her cat litter regularly to avoid infection by toxoplasma during her pregnancy. What is the infective stage of these organisms in the cat feces?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

oocyst The cat,specifically the definitive host, is responsible for the sexual reproduction of Toxoplasma gondii. Inside the cat’s intestines, the parasite produces oocysts. These oocysts are then shed in cat’s feces. After being shed in the environment,the oocysts require a period of time, usually 1 to 5 days to undergo sporulation. Sporulation makes the oocysts infective.

Highyeild:

Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan parasite that infects most species of warm-blooded animals, including humans, and causes the disease toxoplasmosis. Life cycle of T. gondii The triad consists of the following three features: Chorioretinitis: Chorioretinitis refers to inflammation of the retina and choroid, which are the layers at the back of the eye. It can lead to vision problems, including blurry vision, visual field defects, and even blindness. Chorioretinitis is a common ocular manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis and can occur later in childhood or even adulthood. Hydrocephalus : Hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid within the brain's ventricles, leading to increased pressure. It can result in an enlarged head size in infants due to the expanding ventricles. Hydrocephalus can cause a range of neurological symptoms, including headaches, vomiting, irritability, and developmental delays. Intracranial Calcifications: Intracranial calcifications are the presence of calcified deposits within the brain tissue. These calcifications can be seen on imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) scans or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). They may be associated with neurological symptoms and developmental delays.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Tachyzoite : Once inside the intermediate host,the oocysts release sporozoites that invade the host’s cells. The sporozoites rapidly multiply and transform into tachyzoites,which Option C. Bradyzoite : The tachyzoites can invade various tissues and organs,where they transform into a dormant,slow -growing form called bradyzoites. These bradyzoites form tissue cysts primarily in the brain,muscle tissue and other organs of the intermediate host. Option D. Gametocyte : Inside the cat’s intestines,the bradyzoites develop into male and female gametes which form zygotes. The zygotes develop into oocysts,which are then shed in the cat’s feces,completing the cycle.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who underwent a kidney transplant 10 years back is on immunosuppressive therapy. He gives a history of cough and dyspnea for the past 1 week, and the sputum microscopy shows gram- positive budding yeasts cells and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Invasive candidiasis Invasive candidiasis occurs when Candida yeast gets into your bloodstream and spreads to internal organs.

Highyeild:

Candidiasis, also known as a yeast infection, is a fungal infection caused by the Candida species of yeast. While Candida normally resides on the skin and in mucous membranes without causing harm, overgrowth can lead to infections. Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi . They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae. It appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears . Mycelial forms suggest colonization Clinical spectrum of Candidal infections Oral Candidiasis (Thrush): Affects the mouth and throat. Presents as white patches on the tongue, inner cheeks, and roof of the mouth. Genital Candidiasis (Vaginal Yeast Infection): Affects the vagina and vulva in females, and the penis in males. Causes itching, burning, and white, cottage cheese-like discharge. Cutaneous Candidiasis: Affects skin in warm, moist areas, such as under breasts, groin, and folds of skin. Causes red, itchy, and sometimes painful rash. Invasive Candidiasis: Affects internal organs and bloodstream, often in hospitalized patients with weakened immune systems. Can lead to serious bloodstream infections Antifungal Medications: Topical creams, ointments, antifungal i.e clotrimazole, nystatin medications amd oral fluconazole are commonly prescribed. Risk factors for candidiasis: Weakened Immune System: Individuals with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients, transplant recipients) are more susceptible. Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes can create favorable conditions for yeast overgrowth. Antibiotics: Disrupt the balance of normal flora, allowing Candida to proliferate. Pregnancy: Hormonal changes can encourage yeast growth. Medications: Corticosteroids and immunosuppressants can increase the risk. Damp Environments: Humidity and moisture create ideal conditions for yeast growth.

questions.text: Protein misfolding is associated with disease called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prion disease Prion diseases are transmissible, untreatable, and fatal brain diseases of mammals. Their cause is highly unusual: The host's normal prion protein can, for unknown reasons, malfunction and assemble into structured aggregates called prions that cause infectious brain disease.

Highyeild:

Protein misfolding within cells may cause disease by creating a deficiency of an essential protein or by inducing apoptosis. Misfolded proteins often lose their activity and are rapidly degraded, both of which can contribute to a loss of function. If this function is essential, cellular injury ensues. Cell death as a result of protein misfolding is recognized as a feature of a number of diseases, including the neurodegenerative disorders Alzheimer disease, Huntington disease, and Parkinson disease

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Wilson's disease The disorder is caused by autosomal recessive mutations (defects inherited from both parents) in a gene known as ATP7B, which produces a membrane protein that regulates the transport of copper out of cells. Option C. Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver tissue. Some people with hepatitis have no symptoms, whereas others develop yellow discoloration of the skin. Option D . Amyloid disease is a rare disease that occurs when a protein called amyloid builds up in organs such as kidney,liver,heart,brain.
